text: it's another big day of volatility on
the markets today driven mainly by
Europe where there's concern about a
Greek default and what this might mean
for banks principally the three big
French banks that hold a lot of Greek
debt we now seem to be in a period of
unprecedented volatility the same sort
of levels of volatility that were
witnessed in the Great Depression and in
2008 in the financial crisis in August
there were four days of consecutive 4%
swings we went back and looked at data
since nineteen sixty and we found that
while today is about as volatile as it
was and say in the 60s and 70s these
four percent swings these big swings in
the stock market are happening now more
frequently the inflection point in the
US economy whether we're going into
recession or whether the authorities the
Federal Reserve will step in all that
uncertainty is causing these great falls
some days and recoveries on others
similarly in Europe fears about where
this great indebtedness will lead and at
the same time what the ECB or the
government's would do to step in to save
Europe are causing great declines in the
stock market and great recoveries
